paper.title: Phase-curve Evidence for an Atmosphere on TRAPPIST-1 b

core_question: Does TRAPPIST-1 b, an Earth-sized rocky planet orbiting an M dwarf, retain an atmosphere under strong stellar irradiation?

datasets_or_cohorts.label: Observed planetary system
datasets_or_cohorts.sample_size_or_observations: One rocky exoplanet with phase-resolved thermal spectra
datasets_or_cohorts.description: TRAPPIST-1 b observed with JWST MIRI low-resolution spectroscopy over an orbital phase curve, measuring thermal phase variation and spectral structure.

datasets_or_cohorts.label: Bare-rock null scenario
datasets_or_cohorts.description: No-atmosphere model with minimal heat redistribution, serving as the null hypothesis comparator for the atmospheric detection analysis.

datasets_or_cohorts.label: CO2-rich atmosphere scenario
datasets_or_cohorts.description: Atmosphere model with significant greenhouse gas absorption, particularly featuring CO2 spectral signatures around the 15 micron band.

datasets_or_cohorts.label: O2-rich atmosphere scenario
datasets_or_cohorts.description: Oxidized atmospheric composition scenario with weaker CO2 signature constraints, representing an alternative atmospheric chemistry hypothesis.

major_limitations: This is a single-planet study and does not establish atmospheric prevalence across all M-dwarf rocky planets.
Retrieval assumptions (circulation, opacity priors, cloud treatment) affect quantitative posteriors.
Stellar variability and instrument systematics can bias weak spectral features.
Night-side constraints are weaker than day-side constraints in the current dataset.
Degeneracies between composition, clouds/hazes, and circulation assumptions remain significant.
